Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Story:
I stood in my kitchen, glancing out the window at the row of trash bins lining the curb. My neighbor, Mrs. Patel, had just texted the group chat, reminding everyone to be mindful of space and not to put out half-empty bins. She’d mentioned how the city was cracking down on waste, and I knew she expected me to wait until next week. But my own bin was already out, only half-full, and I felt a twinge of guilt. 

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my manager: “Need your time estimates for the new project by noon.” I stared at the spreadsheet, my mind racing with dependencies and unknowns. The team was waiting on me, and management needed solid numbers to plan the quarter. I felt the pressure mounting—if I focused on the trash, I’d lose precious time for work; if I ignored the neighborly request, I’d risk tension on the block. My roles as a considerate neighbor and a responsible engineer were pulling me in opposite directions, and I could feel the stress knotting in my chest as I tried to decide what to do next.
